body: `sizeof` for compile-time-known-size arrays will return (or rather be replaced by) `size * sizeof(T)` where `T` is type of array's elements. What's more - `_countof` is nonstandard macro defined on msvc only. What you would rather use, if you don't want `sizeof`, is [`std::extent`](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/types/extent).
@LaurentGomila Isn't this a genuine bug? If `sizeof(TCHAR)` is not 1, this might cause a stack buffer overflow.
No, since `errBuff` is also of type `TCHAR`, so it will always have the correct length. In this example, `sizeof(errBuff)` will be equal to `256 * sizeof(TCHAR)`.
Yeah but `FormatMessage` takes the number of `TCHAR`s, not the size of the buffer (if I'm reading MSDN correctly).

Yep, rereading MSDN it seems  you're actually right. It's supposed to be the number of `TCHAR` rather than the memory/buffer size.

So simple solution would be using `256` in this case.
Just rewrote the function in question to just use system allocated memory (something Joystick implementation does as well).

In my opinion, TCHAR and the whole set of types and macros that depend on UNICODE, should never be used. We should directly call the A or W version of the function with either char or wchar_t, and correctly deal with that.

That's supposed to be the standard rule when dealing with the Win32 API in SFML code (look at WindowImplWin32.cpp for example).
Yep, I agree. We should just use the wide character versions everywhere. All supported Windows versions support it anyway.

issue.title: Fixed potential buffer overrun in Win32 OpenGL error handling

body: FWIW, I usually go with what LaurentGomila suggeted; be explicit with char/wchar_t and A or W.
Yep, but think should do that in a separate commit with other similar changes. There are many calls like that hidden throughout the Windows implementation.
